question: What is the general shape of the orbits of the major planets around the Sun?

content.source_1: The measured orbital eccentricities e of the eight major planets are all greater than zero and less than one: Mercury ≈0.206, Venus ≈0.007, Earth ≈0.017, Mars ≈0.093, Jupiter ≈0.049, Saturn ≈0.056, Uranus ≈0.047, Neptune ≈0.009.
content.source_2: In orbital mechanics, a bound orbit is a perfect circle only if e = 0; any bound orbit with 0 < e < 1 is an ellipse.
content.source_3: For most major planets, e is small (typically < 0.06), so at common plotting scales their paths appear essentially circular.
content.source_4: Introductory astronomy texts and classroom diagrams often portray planetary orbits as circles and adopt circular-orbit assumptions to simplify explanations.
content.source_5: All eight major planets move around the Sun in the same (prograde) direction and have small inclinations relative to Earth’s orbital plane, so their orbits are nearly coplanar.
content.source_6: In many practical computations (e.g., quick planning or first-order predictions), treating the planets’ heliocentric paths as circular with uniform angular speed yields close approximations.

answer: Planetary orbits are mostly elliptical in shape.
